standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366905
standard.description: Standards for Mathematical Practice

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366906
standard.description: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366907
standard.description: Reason abstractly and quantitatively.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366908
standard.description: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366909
standard.description: Model with mathematics.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366910
standard.description: Use appropriate tools strategically.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366911
standard.description: Attend to precision.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366912
standard.description: Look for and make use of structure.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2366913
standard.description: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143409
standard.description: Counting and Cardinality

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340E
standard.description: Know number names and the count sequence.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143417
standard.description: 1. Count to 100 by ones and by tens.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143418
standard.description: 2. Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143419
standard.description: 3. Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340F
standard.description: Count to tell the number of objects.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341A
standard.description: 4. Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143695
standard.description: a. When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143696
standard.description: b. Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143697
standard.description: c. Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341B
standard.description: 5. Count to answer "how many?" questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1-20, count out that many objects.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143410
standard.description: Compare numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341C
standard.description: 6. Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group, e.g., by using matching and counting strategies.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341D
standard.description: 7. Compare two numbers between 1 and 10 presented as written numerals.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340A
standard.description: Operations and Algebraic Thinking

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143411
standard.description: Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking from.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341E
standard.description: 1. Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings, sounds (e.g., claps), acting out situations, verbal explanations, expressions, or equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114341F
standard.description: 2. Solve addition and subtraction word problems, and add and subtract within 10, e.g., by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143420
standard.description: 3. Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143421
standard.description: 4. For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer with a drawing or equation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143422
standard.description: 5. Fluently add and subtract within 5.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342D
standard.description: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143438
standard.description: 1. Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143439
standard.description: 2. Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390245
standard.description: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143453
standard.description: 1. Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342E
standard.description: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343A
standard.description: 3. Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343B
standard.description: 4. Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342F
standard.description: Add and subtract within 20.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343C
standard.description: 5. Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343D
standard.description: 6. Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 - 4 = 13 - 3 - 1 = 10 - 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 - 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390246
standard.description: Add and subtract within 20.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143454
standard.description: 2. Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies. By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143430
standard.description: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343E
standard.description: 7. Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114343F
standard.description: 8. Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114344F
standard.description: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143455
standard.description: 3. Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143456
standard.description: 4. Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346D
standard.description: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143477
standard.description: 1. Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 Ã— 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143478
standard.description: 2. Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 Ã· 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143479
standard.description: 3. Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347A
standard.description: 4. Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346E
standard.description: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347B
standard.description: 5. Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347C
standard.description: 6. Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346F
standard.description: Multiply and divide within 100.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347D
standard.description: 7. Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 Ã— 5 = 40, one knows 40 Ã· 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143470
standard.description: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347E
standard.description: 8. Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114347F
standard.description: 9. Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143490
standard.description: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349A
standard.description: 1. Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 Ã— 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349B
standard.description: 2. Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349C
standard.description: 3. Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143491
standard.description: Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349D
standard.description: 4. Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143492
standard.description: Generate and analyze patterns.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349E
standard.description: 5. Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B6
standard.description: Write and interpret numerical expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434EB
standard.description: 1. Use parentheses, brackets, or braces in numerical expressions, and evaluate expressions with these symbols.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434EC
standard.description: 2. Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B7
standard.description: Analyze patterns and relationships.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434ED
standard.description: 3. Generate two numerical patterns using two given rules. Identify apparent relationships between corresponding terms. Form ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the two patterns, and graph the ordered pairs on a coordinate plane.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340B
standard.description: Number and Operations in Base Ten

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143412
standard.description: Work with numbers 11-19 to gain foundations for place value.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143423
standard.description: 1. Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and some further ones, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each composition or decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 18 = 10 + 8); understand that these numbers are composed of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143431
standard.description: Extend the counting sequence.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143440
standard.description: 1. Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143432
standard.description: Understand place value.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143441
standard.description: 2. Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373200
standard.description: 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones - called a "ten."

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373201
standard.description: The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373202
standard.description: The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143442
standard.description: 3. Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390247
standard.description: Understand place value.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143457
standard.description: 1. Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373203
standard.description: 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens - called a "hundred."

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373204
standard.description: The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143458
standard.description: 2. Count within 1000; skip-count by 5s, 10s, and 100s.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143459
standard.description: 3. Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345A
standard.description: 4. Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143433
standard.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143443
standard.description: 4. Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143444
standard.description: 5. Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143445
standard.description: 6. Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390248
standard.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345B
standard.description: 5. Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345C
standard.description: 6. Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345D
standard.description: 7. Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers, one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345E
standard.description: 8. Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100-900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100-900.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114345F
standard.description: 9. Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143471
standard.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143480
standard.description: 1. Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143481
standard.description: 2. Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143482
standard.description: 3. Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (e.g., 9 Ã— 80, 5 Ã— 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390249
standard.description: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A2
standard.description: 4. Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A3
standard.description: 5. Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A4
standard.description: 6. Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143493
standard.description: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114349F
standard.description: 1. Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A0
standard.description: 2. Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A1
standard.description: 3. Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B8
standard.description: Understand the place value system.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434EE
standard.description: 1. Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434EF
standard.description: 2. Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F0
standard.description: 3. Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143698
standard.description: a. Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 Ã— 100 + 4 Ã— 10 + 7 Ã— 1 + 3 Ã— (1/10) + 9 Ã— (1/100) + 2 Ã— (1/1000).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143699
standard.description: b. Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F1
standard.description: 4. Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B9
standard.description: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F2
standard.description: 5. Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F3
standard.description: 6. Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F4
standard.description: 7. Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340C
standard.description: Measurement and Data

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143413
standard.description: Describe and compare measurable attributes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143424
standard.description: 1. Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143425
standard.description: 2. Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common, to see which object has "more of"/"less of" the attribute, and describe the difference.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143414
standard.description: Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143426
standard.description: 3. Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143434
standard.description: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143446
standard.description: 1. Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143447
standard.description: 2. Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143435
standard.description: Tell and write time.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143448
standard.description: 3. Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143436
standard.description: Represent and interpret data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143449
standard.description: 4. Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390250
standard.description: Represent and interpret data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143468
standard.description: 9. Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143469
standard.description: 10. Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in a bar graph.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390251
standard.description: Represent and interpret data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143488
standard.description: 3. Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step "how many more" and "how many less" problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143489
standard.description: 4. Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units- whole numbers, halves, or quarters.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390252
standard.description: Represent and interpret data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AF
standard.description: 4. Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390253
standard.description: Represent and interpret data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FD
standard.description: 2. Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Use operations on fractions for this grade to solve problems involving information presented in line plots.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143450
standard.description: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143460
standard.description: 1. Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143461
standard.description: 2. Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143462
standard.description: 3. Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143463
standard.description: 4. Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143451
standard.description: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143464
standard.description: 5. Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143465
standard.description: 6. Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143452
standard.description: Work with time and money.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143466
standard.description: 7. Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143467
standard.description: 8. Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and Â¢ symbols appropriately.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143474
standard.description: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143486
standard.description: 1. Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143487
standard.description: 2. Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l). Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143475
standard.description: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348A
standard.description: 5. Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369A
standard.description: a. A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to have "one square unit" of area, and can be used to measure area.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369B
standard.description: b. A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348B
standard.description: 6. Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348C
standard.description: 7. Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369C
standard.description: a. Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369D
standard.description: b. Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369E
standard.description: c. Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a Ã— b and a Ã— c. Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114369F
standard.description: d. Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143476
standard.description: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and distinguish between linear and area measures.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348D
standard.description: 8. Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143497
standard.description: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AC
standard.description: 1. Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two column table.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AD
standard.description: 2. Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AE
standard.description: 3. Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143498
standard.description: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B0
standard.description: 5. Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373205
standard.description: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a "one-degree angle," and can be used to measure angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373206
standard.description: An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B1
standard.description: 6. Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B2
standard.description: 7. Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BC
standard.description: Convert like measurement units within a given measurement system.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FC
standard.description: 1. Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BD
standard.description: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FE
standard.description: 3. Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11436A0
standard.description: a. A cube with side length 1 unit, called a "unit cube," is said to have "one cubic unit" of volume, and can be used to measure volume.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11436A1
standard.description: b. A solid figure which can be packed without gaps or overlaps using n unit cubes is said to have a volume of n cubic units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FF
standard.description: 4. Measure volumes by counting unit cubes, using cubic cm, cubic in, cubic ft, and improvised units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143500
standard.description: 5. Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11436A2
standard.description: a. Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with whole-number side lengths by packing it with unit cubes, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths, equivalently by multiplying the height by the area of the base. Represent threefold whole-number products as volumes, e.g., to represent the associative property of multiplication.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11436A3
standard.description: b. Apply the formulas V = l Ã— w Ã— h and V = b Ã— h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole-number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11436A4
standard.description: c. Recognize volume as additive. Find volumes of solid figures composed of two non-overlapping right rectangular prisms by adding the volumes of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114340D
standard.description: Geometry

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143415
standard.description: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143427
standard.description: 1. Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143428
standard.description: 2. Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143429
standard.description: 3. Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, "flat") or three-dimensional ("solid").

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143416
standard.description: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342A
standard.description: 4. Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/"corners") and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342B
standard.description: 5. Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks and clay balls) and drawing shapes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114342C
standard.description: 6. Compose simple shapes to form larger shapes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143437
standard.description: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114344A
standard.description: 1. Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114344B
standard.description: 2. Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114344C
standard.description: 3. Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of. Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390254
standard.description: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346A
standard.description: 1. Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces. Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346B
standard.description: 2. Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114346C
standard.description: 3. Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2390255
standard.description: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348E
standard.description: 1. Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114348F
standard.description: 2. Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143499
standard.description: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B3
standard.description: 1. Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B4
standard.description: 2. Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434B5
standard.description: 3. Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BE
standard.description: Graph points on the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143501
standard.description: 1. Use a pair of perpendicular number lines, called axes, to define a coordinate system, with the intersection of the lines (the origin) arranged to coincide with the 0 on each line and a given point in the plane located by using an ordered pair of numbers, called its coordinates. Understand that the first number indicates how far to travel from the origin in the direction of one axis, and the second number indicates how far to travel in the direction of the second axis, with the convention that the names of the two axes and the coordinates correspond (e.g., x-axis and x-coordinate, y-axis and y-coordinate).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143502
standard.description: 2. Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BF
standard.description: Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143503
standard.description: 3. Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two-dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143504
standard.description: 4. Classify two-dimensional figures in a hierarchy based on properties.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CA
standard.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E2
standard.description: 1. Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E3
standard.description: 2. Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E4
standard.description: 3. Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E5
standard.description: 4. Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143509
standard.description: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships between them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143518
standard.description: 1. Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143519
standard.description: 2. Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351A
standard.description: 3. Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350A
standard.description: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351B
standard.description: 4. Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351C
standard.description: 5. Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351D
standard.description: 6. Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353C
standard.description: Understand congruence and similarity using physical models, transparencies, or geometry software.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353D
standard.description: 1. Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373207
standard.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373208
standard.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373209
standard.description: Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353E
standard.description: 2. Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the congruence between them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353F
standard.description: 3. Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143540
standard.description: 4. Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the similarity between them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143541
standard.description: 5. Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143542
standard.description: Understand and apply the Pythagorean Theorem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143544
standard.description: 6. Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143545
standard.description: 7. Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143546
standard.description: 8. Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143543
standard.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volume of cylinders, cones, and spheres.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143547
standard.description: 9. Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143472
standard.description: Number and Operations with Fractions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143473
standard.description: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143483
standard.description: 1. Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143484
standard.description: 2. Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368F
standard.description: a. Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143690
standard.description: b. Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths 1/b from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number a/b on the number line.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143485
standard.description: 3. Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143691
standard.description: a. Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143692
standard.description: b. Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143693
standard.description: c. Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143694
standard.description: d. Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143494
standard.description: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A5
standard.description: 1. Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n Ã— a)/(n Ã— b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A6
standard.description: 2. Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143495
standard.description: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A7
standard.description: 3. Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368B
standard.description: a. Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368C
standard.description: b. Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368D
standard.description: c. Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368E
standard.description: d. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A8
standard.description: 4. Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143688
standard.description: a. Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143689
standard.description: b. Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a fraction by a whole number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114368A
standard.description: c. Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143496
standard.description: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434A9
standard.description: 5. Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AA
standard.description: 6. Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434AB
standard.description: 7. Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BA
standard.description: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F5
standard.description: 1. Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F6
standard.description: 2. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434BB
standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F7
standard.description: 3. Interpret a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator (a/b = a Ã· b). Solve word problems involving division of whole numbers leading to answers in the form of fractions or mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F8
standard.description: 4. Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143683
standard.description: a. Interpret the product (a/b) Ã— q as a parts of a partition of q into b equal parts; equivalently, as the result of a sequence of operations a Ã— q Ã· b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143684
standard.description: b. Find the area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths by tiling it with unit squares of the appropriate unit fraction side lengths, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths. Multiply fractional side lengths to find areas of rectangles, and represent fraction products as rectangular areas.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434F9
standard.description: 5. Interpret multiplication as scaling (resizing), by:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373210
standard.description: Comparing the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor, without performing the indicated multiplication.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373211
standard.description: Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (nÃ—a)/(nÃ—b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FA
standard.description: 6. Solve real world problems involving multiplication of fractions and mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434FB
standard.description: 7. Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143685
standard.description: a. Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143686
standard.description: b. Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143687
standard.description: c. Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C0
standard.description: Ratios and Proportional Relationships

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C1
standard.description: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CE
standard.description: 1. Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CF
standard.description: 2. Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b â‰ 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D0
standard.description: 3. Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367F
standard.description: a. Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143680
standard.description: b. Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143681
standard.description: c. Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143682
standard.description: d. Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units; manipulate and transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143505
standard.description: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350E
standard.description: 1. Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350F
standard.description: 2. Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367B
standard.description: a. Decide whether two quantities are in a proportional relationship, e.g., by testing for equivalent ratios in a table or graphing on a coordinate plane and observing whether the graph is a straight line through the origin.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367C
standard.description: b. Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367D
standard.description: c. Represent proportional relationships by equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367E
standard.description: d. Explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation, with special attention to the points (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143510
standard.description: 3. Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C2
standard.description: The Number System

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C3
standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D1
standard.description: 1. Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C4
standard.description: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D2
standard.description: 2. Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D3
standard.description: 3. Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D4
standard.description: 4. Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1-100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C5
standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D5
standard.description: 5. Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values (e.g., temperature above/below zero, elevation above/below sea level, credits/debits, positive/negative electric charge); use positive and negative numbers to represent quantities in real-world contexts, explaining the meaning of 0 in each situation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D6
standard.description: 6. Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143674
standard.description: a. Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., -(-3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143675
standard.description: b. Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143676
standard.description: c. Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D7
standard.description: 7. Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143677
standard.description: a. Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143678
standard.description: b. Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143679
standard.description: c. Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114367A
standard.description: d. Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D8
standard.description: 8. Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143506
standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143511
standard.description: 1. Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143670
standard.description: a. Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143671
standard.description: b. Understand p + q as the number located a distance |q| from p, in the positive or negative direction depending on whether q is positive or negative. Show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Interpret sums of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143672
standard.description: c. Understand subtraction of rational numbers as adding the additive inverse, p - q = p + (-q). Show that the distance between two rational numbers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference, and apply this principle in real-world contexts.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143673
standard.description: d. Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143512
standard.description: 2. Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366C
standard.description: a. Understand that multiplication is extended from fractions to rational numbers by requiring that operations continue to satisfy the properties of operations, particularly the distributive property, leading to products such as (-1)(-1) = 1 and the rules for multiplying signed numbers. Interpret products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366D
standard.description: b. Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then -(p/q) = (-p)/q = p/(-q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366E
standard.description: c. Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366F
standard.description: d. Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143513
standard.description: 3. Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143527
standard.description: Know that there are numbers that are not rational, and approximate them by rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143528
