standard.description: 1. Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion; for rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually, and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143529
standard.description: 2. Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions (e.g., Ï€Â²).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C6
standard.description: Expressions and Equations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C7
standard.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434D9
standard.description: 1. Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DA
standard.description: 2. Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143669
standard.description: a. Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366A
standard.description: b. Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient); view one or more parts of an expression as a single entity.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114366B
standard.description: c. Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DB
standard.description: 3. Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DC
standard.description: 4. Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C8
standard.description: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DD
standard.description: 5. Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DE
standard.description: 6. Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434DF
standard.description: 7. Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E0
standard.description: 8. Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434C9
standard.description: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E1
standard.description: 9. Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143507
standard.description: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143514
standard.description: 1. Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143515
standard.description: 2. Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143508
standard.description: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143516
standard.description: 3. Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143517
standard.description: 4. Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143667
standard.description: a. Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143668
standard.description: b. Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352A
standard.description: Work with radicals and integer exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352D
standard.description: 1. Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352E
standard.description: 2. Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form xÂ² = p and xÂ³ = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that âˆš2 is irrational.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352F
standard.description: 3. Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143530
standard.description: 4. Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352B
standard.description: Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143531
standard.description: 5. Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143532
standard.description: 6. Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114352C
standard.description: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143533
standard.description: 7. Solve linear equations in one variable.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143662
standard.description: a. Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143663
standard.description: b. Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143534
standard.description: 8. Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143664
standard.description: a. Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143665
standard.description: b. Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143666
standard.description: c. Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CB
standard.description: Statistics and Probability

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CC
standard.description: Develop understanding of statistical variability.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E6
standard.description: 1. Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E7
standard.description: 2. Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E8
standard.description: 3. Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434CD
standard.description: Summarize and describe distributions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434E9
standard.description: 4. Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11434EA
standard.description: 5. Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373212
standard.description: Reporting the number of observations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373213
standard.description: Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373214
standard.description: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373215
standard.description: Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350B
standard.description: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351E
standard.description: 1. Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114351F
standard.description: 2. Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350C
standard.description: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143520
standard.description: 3. Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143521
standard.description: 4. Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114350D
standard.description: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143522
standard.description: 5. Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143523
standard.description: 6. Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143524
standard.description: 7. Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365D
standard.description: a. Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365E
standard.description: b. Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143525
standard.description: 8. Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365F
standard.description: a. Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143660
standard.description: b. Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., "rolling double sixes"), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143661
standard.description: c. Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143548
standard.description: Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143549
standard.description: 1. Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354A
standard.description: 2. Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354B
standard.description: 3. Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354C
standard.description: 4. Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143526
standard.description: Functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143535
standard.description: Define, evaluate, and compare functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143537
standard.description: 1. Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143538
standard.description: 2. Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143539
standard.description: 3. Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143536
standard.description: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353A
standard.description: 4. Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114353B
standard.description: 5. Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354D
standard.description: High School - Number and Quantity

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143553
standard.description: The Real Number System

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143596
standard.description: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360F
standard.description: 1. Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143610
standard.description: 2. Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143597
standard.description: Use properties of rational and irrational numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143611
standard.description: 3. Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143554
standard.description: Quantities*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143598
standard.description: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143612
standard.description: 1. Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143613
standard.description: 2. Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143614
standard.description: 3. Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143555
standard.description: The Complex Number System

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143599
standard.description: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143615
standard.description: 1. Know there is a complex number i such that iÂ² = -1, and every complex number has the form a + bi with a and b real.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143616
standard.description: 2. Use the relation iÂ² = -1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143617
standard.description: 3. (+) Find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359A
standard.description: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143618
standard.description: 4. (+) Represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143619
standard.description: 5. (+) Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361A
standard.description: 6. (+) Calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359B
standard.description: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361B
standard.description: 7. Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361C
standard.description: 8. (+) Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361D
standard.description: 9. (+) Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra; show that it is true for quadratic polynomials.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143556
standard.description: Vector and Matrix Quantities

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359C
standard.description: Represent and model with vector quantities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361E
standard.description: 1. (+) Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, |v|, ||v||, v).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114361F
standard.description: 2. (+) Find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143620
standard.description: 3. (+) Solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359D
standard.description: Perform operations on vectors.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143621
standard.description: 4. (+) Add and subtract vectors.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143658
standard.description: a. Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143659
standard.description: b. Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365A
standard.description: c. Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143622
standard.description: 5. (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365B
standard.description: a. Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(vx, vy) = (cvx, cvy).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114365C
standard.description: b. Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v ? 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359E
standard.description: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143623
standard.description: 6. (+) Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143624
standard.description: 7. (+) Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143625
standard.description: 8. (+) Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143626
standard.description: 9. (+) Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143627
standard.description: 10. (+) Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143628
standard.description: 11. (+) Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143629
standard.description: 12. (+) Work with 2 Ã— 2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354E
standard.description: High School - Algebra

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143557
standard.description: Seeing Structure in Expressions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358B
standard.description: Interpret the structure of expressions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362A
standard.description: 1. Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context *

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143651
standard.description: a. Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143652
standard.description: b. Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362B
standard.description: 2. Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358C
standard.description: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362C
standard.description: 3. Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143653
standard.description: a. Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143654
standard.description: b. Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143655
standard.description: c. Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362D
standard.description: 4. Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143558
standard.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358D
standard.description: Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362E
standard.description: 1. Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358E
standard.description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114362F
standard.description: 2. Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143630
standard.description: 3. Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358F
standard.description: Use polynomial identities to solve problems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143631
standard.description: 4. Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143632
standard.description: 5. (+) Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)n in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143590
standard.description: Rewrite rational expressions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143633
standard.description: 6. Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write a(x /b(x) in the form q(x) + r(x)/b(x), where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143634
standard.description: 7. (+) Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143559
standard.description: Creating Equations*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143591
standard.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143635
standard.description: 1. Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143636
standard.description: 2. Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143637
standard.description: 3. Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143638
standard.description: 4. Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355A
standard.description: Reasoning with Equations and Inequalities

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143592
standard.description: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143639
standard.description: 1. Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363A
standard.description: 2. Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143593
standard.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363B
standard.description: 3. Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363C
standard.description: 4. Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143656
standard.description: a. Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p)Â² = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143657
standard.description: b. Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for xÂ² = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a Â± bi for real numbers a and b.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143594
standard.description: Solve systems of equations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363D
standard.description: 5. Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363E
standard.description: 6. Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114363F
standard.description: 7. Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143640
standard.description: 8. (+) Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143641
standard.description: 9. (+) Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3 Ã— 3 or greater).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143595
standard.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143642
standard.description: 10. Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143643
standard.description: 11. Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143644
standard.description: 12. Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114354F
standard.description: High School - Functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355B
standard.description: Interpreting Functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143581
standard.description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E9
standard.description: 1. Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435EA
standard.description: 2. Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435EB
standard.description: 3. Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143582
standard.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435EC
standard.description: 4. For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435ED
standard.description: 5. Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435EE
standard.description: 6. Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143583
standard.description: Analyze functions using different representations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435EF
standard.description: 7. Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364A
standard.description: a. Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364B
standard.description: b. Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364C
standard.description: c. Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364D
standard.description: d. (+) Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364E
standard.description: e. Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F0
standard.description: 8. Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114364F
standard.description: a. Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143650
standard.description: b. Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F1
standard.description: 9. Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355C
standard.description: Building Functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143584
standard.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F2
standard.description: 1. Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities *

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F3
standard.description: a. Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F4
standard.description: b. Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F5
standard.description: c. (+) Compose functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F6
standard.description: 2. Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143585
standard.description: Build new functions from existing functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F7
standard.description: 3. Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F8
standard.description: 4. Find inverse functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435F9
standard.description: a. Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FA
standard.description: b. (+) Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FB
standard.description: c. (+) Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FC
standard.description: d. (+) Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FD
standard.description: 5. (+) Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355D
standard.description: Linear, Quadratic, and Exponential Models*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143586
standard.description: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FE
standard.description: 1. Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435FF
standard.description: a. Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143600
standard.description: b. Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143601
standard.description: c. Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143602
standard.description: 2. Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143603
standard.description: 3. Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143604
standard.description: 4. For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to abct = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143587
standard.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143605
standard.description: 5. Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355E
standard.description: Trigonometric Functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143588
standard.description: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143606
standard.description: 1. Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143607
standard.description: 2. Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143608
standard.description: 3. (+) Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for Ï€/3, Ï€/4 and Ï€/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for Ï€-x, Ï€+x, and 2Ï€-x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143609
standard.description: 4. (+) Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143589
standard.description: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360A
standard.description: 5. Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360B
standard.description: 6. (+) Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360C
standard.description: 7. (+) Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114358A
standard.description: Prove and apply trigonometric identities

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360D
standard.description: 8. Prove the Pythagorean identity sinÂ²(Î¸) + cosÂ²(Î¸) = 1 and use it to find sin(Î¸), cos(Î¸), or tan(Î¸) given sin(Î¸), cos(Î¸), or tan(Î¸) and the quadrant of the angle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114360E
standard.description: 9. (+) Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143551
standard.description: High School - Geometry

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114355F
standard.description: Congruence

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143572
standard.description: Experiment with transformations in the plane

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BE
standard.description: 1. Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BF
standard.description: 2. Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C0
standard.description: 3. Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C1
standard.description: 4. Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C2
standard.description: 5. Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143573
standard.description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C3
standard.description: 6. Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C4
standard.description: 7. Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C5
standard.description: 8. Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143574
standard.description: Prove geometric theorems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C6
standard.description: 9. Prove theorems about lines and angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C7
standard.description: 10. Prove theorems about triangles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C8
standard.description: 11. Prove theorems about parallelograms.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143575
standard.description: Make geometric constructions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435C9
standard.description: 12. Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CA
standard.description: 13. Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143560
standard.description: Similarity, Right Triangles, and Trigonometry

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143576
standard.description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CB
standard.description: 1. Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373216
standard.description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S2373217
standard.description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CC
standard.description: 2. Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CD
standard.description: 3. Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143577
standard.description: Prove theorems involving similarity

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CE
standard.description: 4. Prove theorems about triangles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435CF
standard.description: 5. Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143578
standard.description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D0
standard.description: 6. Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D1
standard.description: 7. Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D2
standard.description: 8. Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143579
standard.description: Apply trigonometry to general triangles

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D3
standard.description: 9. (+) Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D4
standard.description: 10. (+) Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D5
standard.description: 11. (+) Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143561
standard.description: Circles

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357A
standard.description: Understand and apply theorems about circles

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D6
standard.description: 1. Prove that all circles are similar.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D7
standard.description: 2. Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D8
standard.description: 3. Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435D9
standard.description: 4. (+) Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357B
standard.description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DA
standard.description: 5. Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143562
standard.description: Expressing Geometric Properties with Equations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357C
standard.description: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DB
standard.description: 1. Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DC
standard.description: 2. Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DD
standard.description: 3. (+) Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357D
standard.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DE
standard.description: 4. Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435DF
standard.description: 5. Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E0
standard.description: 6. Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E1
standard.description: 7. Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143563
standard.description: Geometric Measurement and Dimension

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357E
standard.description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E2
standard.description: 1. Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E3
standard.description: 2. (+) Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E4
standard.description: 3. Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114357F
standard.description: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E5
standard.description: 4. Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143564
standard.description: Modeling with Geometry

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143580
standard.description: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E6
standard.description: 1. Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E7
standard.description: 2. Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435E8
standard.description: 3. Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143552
standard.description: High School - Statistics and Probability*

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143565
standard.description: Interpreting Categorical and Quantitative Data

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143569
standard.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114359F
standard.description: 1. Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A0
standard.description: 2. Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A1
standard.description: 3. Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A2
standard.description: 4. Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356A
standard.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A3
standard.description: 5. Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A4
standard.description: 6. Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143645
standard.description: a. Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143646
standard.description: b. Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143647
standard.description: c. Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356B
standard.description: Interpret linear models

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A5
standard.description: 7. Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A6
standard.description: 8. Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A7
standard.description: 9. Distinguish between correlation and causation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143566
standard.description: Making Inferences and Justifying Conclusions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356C
standard.description: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A8
standard.description: 1. Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435A9
standard.description: 2. Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356D
standard.description: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AA
standard.description: 3. Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AB
standard.description: 4. Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AC
standard.description: 5. Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AD
standard.description: 6. Evaluate reports based on data.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143567
standard.description: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356E
standard.description: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AE
standard.description: 1. Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435AF
standard.description: 2. Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B0
standard.description: 3. Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B1
standard.description: 4. Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B2
standard.description: 5. Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S114356F
standard.description: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B3
standard.description: 6. Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B4
standard.description: 7. Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B5
standard.description: 8. (+) Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B6
standard.description: 9. (+) Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143568
standard.description: Using Probability to Make Decisions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143570
standard.description: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B7
standard.description: 1. (+) Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B8
standard.description: 2. (+) Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435B9
standard.description: 3. (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BA
standard.description: 4. (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143571
standard.description: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BB
standard.description: 5. (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143648
standard.description: a. Find the expected payoff for a game of chance.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S1143649
standard.description: b. Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BC
standard.description: 6. (+) Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).

standard.name: http://asn.jesandco.org/resources/S11435BD
standard.description: 7. (+) Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).
